verses.text: Then the LORD spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: No major differences; literal rendering of direct speech introduction.

verses.text: “Tell the people of Israel to turn back and camp in front of Pi-hahiroth, between Migdol and the sea, opposite Baal-zephon; you shall camp facing it by the sea.
verses.comment: Ancient place names preserved; 'camp facing it by the sea' reflects Hebrew.

verses.text: For Pharaoh will say of the people of Israel, ‘They are wandering in the land; the wilderness has shut them in.’
verses.comment: Literal rendering of Pharaoh's presumed thoughts.

verses.text: And I will harden Pharaoh’s heart, and he will pursue them, and I will get glory over Pharaoh and all his army, and the Egyptians shall know that I am the LORD.” And they did so.
verses.comment: ‘Get glory over’ literal of Hebrew idiom for manifesting God's power.

verses.text: When the king of Egypt was told that the people had fled, the heart of Pharaoh and his servants was changed toward the people, and they said, “What is this we have done, that we have let Israel go from serving us?”
verses.comment: Faithful to the Hebrew; keeps direct question.

verses.text: So he made his chariot ready and took his people with him.
verses.comment: Simple, literal rendering.

verses.text: And he took six hundred chosen chariots and all the other chariots of Egypt with officers over all of them.
verses.comment: ‘Chosen chariots’ per traditional translations; ‘officers’ for Hebrew shalishim (third men, elite soldiers/officers).

verses.text: And the LORD hardened the heart of Pharaoh king of Egypt, and he pursued after the people of Israel, while the people of Israel were going out boldly.
verses.comment: ‘Going out boldly’ reflects the Hebrew, ‘with a high hand’—confidently.

verses.text: The Egyptians pursued them—all Pharaoh’s horses and chariots and his horsemen and his army—and overtook them encamped by the sea, by Pi-hahiroth, in front of Baal-zephon.
verses.comment: Lists all parts of Egyptian force as in Hebrew.

verses.text: When Pharaoh drew near, the people of Israel lifted up their eyes, and behold, the Egyptians were marching after them, and they were very afraid. So the people of Israel cried out to the LORD.
verses.comment: ‘Lifted up their eyes’ is a literal Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: They said to Moses, “Is it because there are no graves in Egypt that you have taken us away to die in the wilderness? What have you done to us by bringing us out of Egypt?
verses.comment: Sarcastic question preserved as in the original.

verses.text: Is this not what we said to you in Egypt: ‘Leave us alone, so that we may serve the Egyptians’? For it would have been better for us to serve the Egyptians than to die in the wilderness.”
verses.comment: Renders rhetorical statement and comparison faithfully.

verses.text: But Moses said to the people, “Do not be afraid. Stand firm, and see the salvation of the LORD, which he will work for you today. For the Egyptians whom you see today, you will never see again.
verses.comment: ‘Salvation’ used as in Hebrew; direct speech preserved.

verses.text: The LORD will fight for you, and you shall be still.”
verses.comment: ‘Be still’ is a literal translation of ‘keep silent’.

verses.text: Then the LORD said to Moses, “Why do you cry to me? Tell the people of Israel to go forward.
verses.comment: Direct imperative faithfully rendered.

verses.text: Lift up your staff, and stretch out your hand over the sea and divide it, so the people of Israel may go through the sea on dry ground.
verses.comment: Actions rendered literally per Hebrew verbs.

verses.text: And I will harden the hearts of the Egyptians so that they will go in after them, and I will get glory over Pharaoh and all his army, his chariots, and his horsemen.
verses.comment: Maintains original repetition and titling.

verses.text: And the Egyptians shall know that I am the LORD, when I get glory over Pharaoh, his chariots, and his horsemen.”
verses.comment: ‘Get glory over’ follows Hebrew idiom for God’s reputation.

verses.text: Then the angel of God, who was going before the camp of Israel, moved and went behind them, and the pillar of cloud moved from before them and stood behind them,
verses.comment: ‘Angel of God’ (mal’ak Elohim) distinguished; narrative precise.

verses.text: coming between the camp of Egypt and the camp of Israel. And there was the cloud and the darkness, and it gave light by night, so that neither came near the other all that night.
verses.comment: Hebrew phrasing preserved concerning the pillar’s effect.

verses.text: Then Moses stretched out his hand over the sea, and the LORD drove the sea back by a strong east wind all night and made the sea dry ground, and the waters were divided.
verses.comment: ‘Stretched out his hand’ is a recurring idiom; wind and dividing language faithful to Hebrew.

verses.text: And the people of Israel went into the midst of the sea on dry ground, the waters being a wall to them on their right hand and on their left.
verses.comment: Phrase ‘waters being a wall’ is as close as possible to Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: The Egyptians pursued and went in after them into the midst of the sea, all Pharaoh’s horses, his chariots, and his horsemen.
verses.comment: Order and repetition follows original closely.

verses.text: And in the morning watch, the LORD looked down on the Egyptian army through the pillar of fire and cloud and threw the Egyptian army into confusion.
verses.comment: ‘Morning watch’ is an ancient time reference (just before dawn); ‘threw…into confusion’ matches Hebrew verb.

verses.text: And he clogged their chariot wheels so that they drove them with difficulty. And the Egyptians said, “Let us flee from before Israel, for the LORD fights for them against the Egyptians.”
verses.comment: ‘Clogged’ is literal (removed/loosened/bound up); captures the narrative’s dramatic turn.

verses.text: Then the LORD said to Moses, “Stretch out your hand over the sea, that the waters may come back upon the Egyptians, upon their chariots, and upon their horsemen.”
verses.comment: Direct command as originally.

verses.text: So Moses stretched out his hand over the sea, and the sea returned to its normal course when the morning appeared. And as the Egyptians fled into it, the LORD overthrew the Egyptians in the midst of the sea.
verses.comment: ‘Returned to its normal course’—Hebrew: to usual flow. ‘Overthrew’ literal for causing them to fall.

verses.text: The waters returned and covered the chariots and the horsemen, all the army of Pharaoh that had followed them into the sea; not even one of them remained.
verses.comment: ‘Not even one of them remained’ is a direct literal translation.

verses.text: But the people of Israel walked on dry ground through the sea, and the waters were a wall to them on their right hand and on their left.
verses.comment: Repetition preserved as in the Hebrew text.

verses.text: So the LORD saved Israel that day from the hand of the Egyptians, and Israel saw the Egyptians dead on the seashore.
verses.comment: ‘Saved Israel that day from the hand…’ is literal per Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: And Israel saw the great power that the LORD used against the Egyptians, and the people feared the LORD, and they believed in the LORD and in his servant Moses.
verses.comment: ‘Great power’ literal: ‘hand.’ End of the episode emphasizes Israel’s faith and fear.
